nodes.bodyText: I have a hunch that Windows is changing the newline characters in this file, hence the weird diff. I'll look around for solutions.

I think so too, as I get this message from doing commits:
jtquach@DESKTOP-IST3H2B:~/cbioportal_windows10$ git add core/src/main/java/org/mskcc/cbio/portal/scripts/UpdateGenePanel.java
warning: LF will be replaced by CRLF in core/src/main/java/org/mskcc/cbio/portal/scripts/UpdateGenePanel.java.
The file will have its original line endings in your working directory
moved the conditions out of the else block

System.err.println() displays red text in Eclipse console.
System.out.println() displays black text.
not sure if I should've used a Pair instead, but the type casting messages to Set don't seem to crash anything
After you make the edits lets talk about your options here.
genePanel != null is always true because if genePanel were null, you would NPE inside DaoGenePanel.updatePreview(genePanel, canonicalGenes);
The null check has been removed now (well earlier, but I forgot to respond here)
This should not be static. Rule of thumb with Java - unless something needs to be static, don't make it static.

The functions I changed from ImportGenePanel were importData and main, so getPropertyValue and all other functions were part of the original implementation.
I will keep this in mind, though!
Are you planning to use this in more than 1 place? Right now both propertyName and noSpaceAllowed are effectively constant.
I think I might delete the methods getPropertyValue and getGenes since they're static and already defined in ImportGenePanel, although I'm not sure if that's a good programming practice?
Never mind, getPropertyValue and getGenes are private (not public)
changed to public as part of GenePanelUtil.java
This is pedantic, but I do not like this method name. I generally reserve get method names for true accessors. I would call this extractGenes or something like that.
acknowledged and changed!
Is the property key for the genes ever going to not be gene_list? If no, we don't need the propertyName param.

It looks like this is the history for ImportGenePanel, with the last commit from Jun 3 showing the latest implementation to getGenes.
I'm also wondering if I should put my username as part of the "author" comment in UpdateGenePanel..?
Now I understand what you mean; I think getting rid of propertyName and just using gene_list would be clearer too given the method name
propertyValue == null is always true right now.
When I hover over the propertyValue == null condition in GenePanelUtil.java, IntelliJ says Condition 'propertyValue == null' is always 'false' and 'Simplify provertyValue == null' to false
update: removed propertyValue == null
We have this y/N parsing logic in two places. Let's make a method that parses it and returns a boolean and use it in both places.
Done! I added a public method promptUser which abstracts the logic
Why are these commented out?
ah, I wasn't sure about including it since I'm not sure how to run seed_mini.sql yet (or if I am)

The existing methods in this file all interact with the database in some way. Lets move your utility methods into a seperate class in core/src/main/java/org/mskcc/cbio/portal/util. Put all methods that don't interact with the database directly there.
just to clarify: are you referring to the union/intersection/difference methods that use streams?
Just moved getPropertyValue and getGenes to GenePanelUtil.java (new file) in core\src\main\java\org\mskcc\cbio\portal\util
I have the auto formatter setting on in VS code, hence why so many lines are changed
This is the real change of the commit
I just removed the Java doc comments (since I'm not sure what their purpose is)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -204,10 +202,6 @@ public static void updateGenePanel(GenePanel genePanel, Set<CanonicalGene> canon
     
     /**
      * Prints the genes to be added and removed from a gene panel in the database.
-     *

nodes.bodyText: since this always computes to false; same below
based on IntelliJ code suggestions, just removed references to Generic types
since long geneId is automatically converted to String
needed to implement equals so assertEquals within the unit tests won't throw errors

What are these variables actually doing? You set them all to null, then never reassign them. Look at JdbcUtil.closeAll - all these variables are null checked before anything happens to them. I think you can delete these variables entirely.
Also, I made the genes ,  delimited instead of tab delimited. Not sure that tabs are going to show up consistently on all terminals.
Wow, streams are pretty nifty! Does the :: map/apply toString to CanonicalGene?

Lets pull this out into its own function that returns the genePanelMap. My rule of thumb here is that extracting code into its own method is generally better than a comment explaining a block of code. With a function, it's more reusable, the name of the function servers as the comment, and it has a clear start and end.
You could do this in a single statement, but this is super readable, and I don't think performance is a major concern. Let's keep it this way. Nice job here.
Good rename.

We know the update is happening in a MySQL database - it's the only database we support. :)

ah, I may have to find a Prettier plugin for Eclipse/IntelliJ
edit: never mind, Ctrl+Alt+L formats a file's code
In both cases where this is used, the scanner is created, passed to this method, never used again, and then closed. Why not just create and close the scanner in this method?

turns out after closing a scanner once, that breaks InputStream for the rest of the class forever
(fix was to make the Scanner a class variable)
put both calls to promptUser inside if condition
Make this an actual javadoc comment. Same goes for the other comment like this.
Removed union, intersection, difference since the below suggestion for getAddRemove (committed) makes them obsolete
Added javadoc comments to all public functions in DaoGenePanel.java and GenePanelUtil.java
Same complaint as with getGenes. This is not a getter.

Add javadoc. Also, isUpdating isn't a great name for that variable. It reflects your usage of it, but not necessarily its general usage. In this function, isUpdating determines if you're allowed to have an empty set of genes. It should be named according to that.
Wait, so if a gene cannot be found, we don't return any of the genes? Odd. Was this existing behavior? If so, at the very least, document this in the javadoc for this function
it's existing behavior, but I can document it in the Java doc @return
I never thought of it that way... I think they are functionally equivalent!
We'll circle back to these in the next review. Don't bother with them for now.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,313 @@
+package org.mskcc.cbio.portal.util;

nodes.bodyText: Let's have some logic here that explicitly checks to make sure the gene panel is not null, and errors and exits if it is null
Get rid of casts
Delete
We don't need the duplicate examples for each test case. It just makes this harder to read. It doesn't really add much in terms of additional verification.
Make these class variables, remove the gene sets, create gene sets as local variables in each test case.
Oh that's true, what I mean is that for that specific panel, if you end up removing some genes and you try to import them back, the genes won't have an entry in the sample_profile (I think)
promptUser is a little vague (I may have told you to call the method this). Let's call it confirmContinue

Shouldn't this be logDebug instead of logWarning?

hm, I suppose so since it's not a "warning" the user has to be worried about on their end, but I'm not sure whether to use setCurrentMessage over logDebug
ditto
I reckoned that the red text from the System.err.print looks more alerting than the black text from System.out.print, but yes it is not an error message perse
Delete
Do you mean the class constructor or the genes? The genes are used in the tests but deleting the constructor still lets the tests run and pass
Just to make things even easier to read, I'd do makeGeneSet() instead of new HashSet<>()
for all instances of new HashSet<>()?
Remind me tomorrow and I'll show you a fun way to generify this and then I'll explain why its a bad idea.
Can we wait to grab a database connection until the check for gene panel existence is complete?
Thanks for the note! I've moved line 270 after the gene panel existence check, and will rebase again
Is this a newer feature of Java where class name does not have to be prepended to method call?

According to the Java 1.5 documentation, one can call static methods without their class name. I didn't know this since IntelliJ suggested this import style. I also opted to follow this convention since ImportGenePanel.java also called static methods without their class names.
Just wondering if there was any thought to combining the update functionality into the Import script?
According to Luke, the import and update functionality should be separate from each other

@n1zea144 Leaving them as separate scripts makes it a bit harder to make the mistake of updating an existing gene panel when you instead meant to upload a new version of a gene panel for new samples. I think this is an easy enough mistake- the user copies the gene panel file, vims it, updates the genes, but forgets to change the name of the panel before running the script. By keeping the two scripts separate, we make it so a user that ignores warning messages and just presses enter a bunch cannot end up making this mistake.
It looks like its possible to remove all genes from the panel.  Should we check this and if so, should we prevent this from happening ?

In UpdateGenePanel.java, the user prompt in importData() verifies the changes that will be made to the gene panel, like so:

Other than that, I asked Luke if importing an empty gene panel should allow for the removal of all existing genes, and he stated that behavior sounds reasonable. I suppose if the user wanted to add back the genes, they could pull up an older version of their input file with the gene names.
I'll ping Luke about whether after all genes are removed, that the gene panel should be removed from gene_panel_list as well
ah, so removal of all genes means stop the update script and don't make the deletions

It's not meaningful to have a panel in the database, which samples refer to in sample_profile, that contain no genes.  I'm also not sure what the affect is on the web page.  One approach is to remove the the panel and subsequent records in sample_profile (via cascade), but thats a bit messy and could happen by mistake.
Spoke with @Luke-Sikina via Slack.  Best approach is not to prevent an update which results in empty panel in database.
Oh, does that mean that within UpdateGenePanel, checking if the incoming set of genes is empty and aborting the script is not needed?
Yeah, checking/aborting when the incoming gene list from the panel file is empty should suffice, thanks for the adjustment.
Thank you for the reviews!
I've just updated the markdown file again to reflect that trying to import an empty gene panel will abort the script.
